🔵🔴 #ForçaBarça https://t.co/MvPDKcknUA Starting in October, work to dismantle the Miniestadi will begin, and will last for six months. Once gone, the land will be used for the construction of the New Palau Blaugrana. https://t.co/wKh5QnDPQl Unfortunately, life moves on for everyone and the games that had been played at the Miniestadi are being held this season at the new Johan Cruyff Stadium, which opened on August 27. Barça B, the U19, and the Women’s teams now have a new home adapted to the times. https://t.co/QfsOOcwFw0 During the last decade, the Miniestadi has continued to sell out for pivotal Barça B, U19, and Women’s matches. Especially noteworthy has been the success of the Women's team, which last April celebrated its first berth in the Champions League final. https://t.co/DpB0SntGiD Recently, one of the biggest days of the year at the Miniestadi has been the traditional open training session before the Three Kings holiday. Thousands of children have had their dreams of seeing the Barça players up close come true. https://t.co/1xP7YNHDCV Not just footballers.

The Miniestadi also became great starting point for coaches, including the likes of Pep Guardiola and Luis Enrique, who after gaining promotion with Barça B would become the only Barça managers to win the treble. https://t.co/3huA4MMQek Years later, those same players would hoist Barça’s second Champions League title in Paris. On that day, the Miniestadi packed in 11,000 fans who watched the final against Arsenal on a giant video screen. https://t.co/855K780fQ9 One of the most memorable occurred when Barça B, led by Puyol and Xavi, beat Real Madrid B 5-0 in the playoffs for promotion to the Second Division. https://t.co/Us6pHP57mn At the end of the 90's and after the turn of the century, the Mini bore witness to the emergence of players like Puyol, Xavi Hernández, Valdés, Iniesta, and Leo Messi, among many others.

With them on the field, Barça’s little coliseum would experience many unforgettable nights. https://t.co/IZUwEXP82S In the summer of 1992, when Camp Nou was being used for the Olympics, the Miniestadi hosted the official presentation of the 1992/93 first team squad. The same happened again in 1994, while work was being carried out at Camp Nou. https://t.co/ZBSIMpR9Jt During the 1980's and 1990's the Miniestadi hosted numerous world-class music concerts featuring the likes of Bob Dylan, Carlos Santana, Queen, David Bowie and Elton John. https://t.co/nI7uXcWo1I First, however, the home of Barça B and other youth teams would fill up for the first time in the last 16 of the 1983/84 Copa del Rey. Barça Athletic (the former name of the Barça reserve team) hosted Real Madrid’s first team ... and drew 0-0! On that first day, the Miniestadi hosted stars like Maradona & Schuster, and a boy named Guillermo Amor, who would become one of the pillars of Cruyff's Dream Team.
It was just the beginning. The Miniestadi was about to witness the emergence of a unique generation of footballers https://t.co/ZgYuVvFXEN Built by the architect Josep Casals and project manager Ramon Domènech, the Miniestadi opened on September 23, 1982, after just nine months of construction. It had a capacity for 15,276, distributed in two levels, with a covered grandstand. https://t.co/1t4MctTH1y Yesterday, the Miniestadi, the laboratory for the best generation of soccer players in Barça history, turned 37 years old. It will be the last birthday before it is demolished as part of the Espai Barça project.
